Fields.DialogueText: Capitán! We have Morganas heading our way from the north!
You sound almost... excited about that.
Por supuesto! I'm eager to show off what my artillery can do for you, Capitán. We simply must hurry and face them.

Fields.MenuText: If you're so confident, then there's no time to waste. Let's get ready for a victory.
Don't be so foolhardy. We should approach carefully and strategically. This is war after all.
No. We'll let them come to us while we stay here and prepare for the skirmish. Sometimes the best offense is a good defense, Velasco.

Fields.DialogueText: Gracias, Capitán. With a brave leader like you leading us, I'm positive this will be the first of many victories to come.
If that is your command, Capitán.
Hmph. You may be right, but that doesn't mean I have to like it.
@BATTLE
Now, sound the alarm and prepare for battle.
Sí, Capitán!
Now, sound the alarm and prepare for battle.
Sí, Capitán!
And while we wait for the enemy to arrive I might have to run around the ship a few times.
As long as you continue to attend to your duties on this ship.
You don't have to worry about that. The ship and the people on board are my first priority.
Take it easy, Velasco. The ship's running smoothly and the horizon is clear of enemy contacts. Most people would be taking a break right about now, so why are you running laps?
I'm not most people. Too much energy to lounge about! I feel like I need to do something.
And by "do something" you mean run laps around the ship?
I'm open to suggestions if you have any.

Fields.MenuText: You could get to know the crew a little better. Maybe they have something you could help with.
Just keep an eye out for any approaching Morganas. I don't want to be caught unawares because you were too preoccupied.
I don't have anything. Keep up the good work.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmmmm, that's actually an excellent idea. Thank you, Capitán, I'll get right on that.
You don't have to worry about Morganas, Capitán. It would take a lot more than a little running to distract me.
I will. Maybe you can join me, sometime.
Velasco? Is something wrong?
Morganas detected! Approaching from the northwest, Capitán.
Well, looks like it's time to use some of that boundless energy of yours, Velasco.
Finally!
@BATTLE
Just don't be too much of a distraction to anyone while they're working. We don't want...
You're right. I trust you'd sense any Morganas that got...
Maybe I will, when I have some free...
Capitán, are you busy? I wanted to get your help with something, if you have the time.
Of course. Come on in, Velasco. What can I help you with?
I've been speaking to some of the crew and they've been very nice to me. I even feel like I'm making a few new friends.
Great! I'm glad to hear it. But how exactly do you need my help?
Well... most of the crew has been very kind, but some have seemed awkward around me.
There are people who prefer to be alone. Not everyone likes making new friends. But then again, maybe they're just not used to being around a Belle.
I suppose meeting a Belle for the first time could leave one at a loss for words.

Fields.MenuText: Don't try to make friends with everyone. Enjoy the ones you have.
Keep trying. Eventually, they'll warm up to you.
Keep your distance if they seem uncomfortable. Let them do their job.

Fields.DialogueText: I know how important friends are. I keep a place in my heart for them, right next to Spain.
I suppose that's one way to make friends, Capitán.
You're right, I don't have to make friends with everyone.
There's the alarm. Let's save making friends for later and start taking care of some enemies.
That sounds like a plan I can get behind!
@BATTLE
Hey, Velasco, I've been meaning to ask about that symbol you're wearing.
Oh, this? It's a V. It's a symbol for "victory."
Oh, of course. That makes a lot of sense for you.
What's that supposed to mean, Capitán?

Fields.MenuText: Nothing, it's just very... you.
You love to show off those guns of yours.
It makes more sense than V for "Velasco".

Fields.DialogueText: I'll take that as a compliment.
Well, can you blame me? My artillery isn't only poderoso, it's maravilloso too.
Maybe if I'm lucky, one day the two will be synonymous!
Well, Let's hope that symbol is a glowing beacon in the battles ahead of us.
Just don't give it all of the credit. I'm here too, after all.
Of course, and I'm very thankful for all your hard work. I'll be relying on you.
Captain, Miss Velasco, I'm about to sound the alarm. We have Morganas inbound.
Well, Capitán, looks like we'll get some use out of our symbol soon enough. Let's go!
After you.
@BATTLE
Captain, if you have time, I'd like to talk to you about the lady of the ship.
Did Velasco do something?
No, it's nothing like that. It's just that some of the crew has noticed that she doesn't seem in the best shape.
What do you mean?
Well she hasn't been eating much lately, in favor of giving her share to others.
She's also got the engineers and the metalworkers "conserving supplies" when it comes to repairs - gambling on patchwork fixes. And I won't even get started with her running.
I'll talk to her. She should take better care of herself.
Thank you, Captain.
Velasco, what are we going to do with you?
Did you say my name, Capitán?
What, uh...

Fields.MenuText: No! I was just trying to think of something that rhymed with... relaxed toe.
No, you must've been hearing things. And don't sneak up on me.
Yes, I was just looking for you, actually.

Fields.DialogueText: Unused crow, evening snow, stolen bow. Why are we rhyming?
Sorry, Capitán, but if you didn't hear me running toward you, that's your own fault.
What can I help you with, Capitán?
Oh, look at that, there goes the alarm. Those Morganas sure have lousy timing. We'll pick this back up after the battle.
@BATTLE
Velasco, I was hoping to speak with you for a moment.
Of course. Just allow me to finish up here first, Capitán.
Now, my good officer, you shouldn't have any more problems. If you do, just remember what I said, all right?
Of course. Thanks, Velasco. Sorry for the trouble.
No trouble at all. I'm always here to help!
Now what did you need from me, Capitán?
What was that about?
Oh, that? Some of the crew told me they were having trouble with one of the torpedo tubes. I came down to help them.

Fields.MenuText: How did you help?
What's wrong with it?
See? There's plenty to do on the ship besides running laps.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't really do anything. There are just a few tricks you have to know to use some of the equipment on board.
Nothing, really. It's just developed a little... character from all the battles it's been in.
Yes, you're right. I've found many uses of my time, lately.
Now what did you need from me?
That'll have to wait. Sounds like we have Morganas to deal with right now.
@BATTLE
Velasco, how are you holding up? I thought I saw you take a bad hit in that last battle.
Capitán, you don't have to worry about me!
Estoy bien. I've taken far worse than that!

Fields.MenuText: You really have to start taking better care of yourself. The crew notices when their Belle is running herself ragged.
I'm sure you have, but still, you should let me have a look.
It's my job to worry about you. I wouldn't be a good captain otherwise.

Fields.DialogueText: I am perfectly fine. There's nothing ragged about me.
Fine! If you feel that you must, go ahead.
Well, you certainly are that. I suppose there are worse things than being worried about.
So, listen - I want the ship looked at when we get to port. Every loose connection in the electrical system, every emergency application of solder.
Given the wear we put you through, I'd like to be as thorough in our repairs and preparations as we can possibly be.
Capitán, that won't be necessary. I'll be fine with whatever repairs we can make at sea. Like I said, I've had worse.
Velasco, you need to start making yourself a higher priority. It's not healthy to put everyone else first at the cost of your own well being.
You don't hear me complaining, do you? I can take care of everyone on this ship, including myself.
Velasco...
We can argue about this later. I sense Morganas nearby.
Right. But we will come back to this subject.
Si insiste.
@BATTLE
Excuse me, Capitán. If you're not too busy, I was hoping to talk.
Sure, I was just finishing with some correspondence. Come in!
I wanted to apologize for how I acted before. I didn't mean to start a fight. It was just that the idea of wasting money and time on thorough repairs at dock seemed... outlandish.
Why? Surely you want to stay safe.
¡Por supuesto! It's just that Spain's economy hasn't been at it's best for some time now. I've had to make do with patches for so long that anything else seems foreign to me.
But if you think full repairs are what's necessary, then I'll follow your orders.

Fields.MenuText: That is my order, but it's only because I want to avoid you getting hurt.
I'm not going to order you to get full repairs, but I'd like you to think about it doing it of your own volition.
You can do what you want. You are the ship, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Capitán. I understand.
I'll consider it, Capitán. Thank you for understanding.
I think I'll stick with my patches for now, but I'll keep repairs in mind if the worst occurs.
If that's all, it sounds like the Morganas heard us talking about them.
Let's teach them not to eavesdrop, Capitán!
@BATTLE
Capitán, Morganas are headed this direction.
Of course they are.
@BATTLE
Capitán, I think you may have been right about my needing repairs.

Fields.MenuText: Oh really? What changed your mind?
That's no surprise. I'm right about most things.
I've changed my mind, too. Our safety is my business as much as yours.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, one of my patches decided to fall apart during that last battle...
Condescension aside, I think you need to look at this.
I see... I guess we won't avoid the issue any longer, then.
I've got extensive flooding belowdecks, and the radio is fried. I'm afraid I really do require more extensive repairs, now.
That's nothing to be ashamed of. We'll work something out next time we make port. Until then, we'll avoid any unnecessary battles.
Thank you, Capitán.
What an experience this has been! You know, I've never made repairs on a Belle's ship before!
That does nothing to reassure me.
Just hold tight, Velasco. I know the process might be a little uncomfortable, but it will be worth it in the end.
Just... tell them to hurry up, would you?
We're almost done here, so you can relax. Most of the damage was superficial, so repairs weren't too involved.
I'll relax when you're gone and I don't feel like I'm under a magnifying glass anymore.
How does it feel, missing so many of your patches?
Odd, really. I feel funny, like I'm missing half of my armor.
Didn't you ask that when they first removed the patches? Why are you asking again?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, did we talk about this before? My memory has been a little funny lately.
I'm trying to distract you with small talk. That way, this process won't feel like it's taking so long.
A captain worries.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, well try and stay sharp. War is no place to go senile.
That's a good idea. It's wonderful weather we're having today. The other day I was thinking of Spain and I started missing my sisters. I'm starting to get a little hungry.
You worry a lot. I'm starting to worry about your worrying.
*ALARM*
Is that the alarm?
It is. Is Velasco seaworthy?
She should be fine for now. Still, on a warship the repairs never end...
Wonderful.
Be nice, Velasco.
@BATTLE
Capitán, how much longer do we have to spend here at dock? With them?
I have a name, you know.
Do you know my name?
Um... Don't remind me. It's... something... with a V? Vasquez?
Velasco.
Ah, yes, Velasco.
Before you go, I wanted to ask about alterations. Your thoughts?
I don't think we can easily replace the 4-inch guns, but we may be able to get new mounts. The electricians think a fairly radical overhaul of your wiring is doable as well, and...
Alterations? Why do I need alterations? Why can't it all remain... like it was?
An opportunity for getting better equipment could make a big difference, down the road.
My thoughts exactly.

Fields.MenuText: It could be cuter.
It could be more elegant.
Let's make it hotter!

Fields.DialogueText: If I have to choose between cute and deadly, I'd choose deadly.
I believe I bring more than enough elegance to the table with my artillery.
Hotter?! What are you talking about, Capitán?
Nothing has been decided yet. We've only worked out some rough sketches so far.
You've already drawn sketches?!
*ALARM*
We can talk more about this after we deal with the Morganas.
You better believe we're going to talk about this.
@BATTLE
So, Velasco, have you had a chance to look over those sketches yet?
Yes, and I am not happy, Capitán.
They're not that bad. Plus, you have to keep in mind that they're rough sketches. I'm sure the final product will look even better.
It's not that. I'm unhappy that you didn't include me at the start. I could've helped you avoid a lot of the problems I'm seeing.
Sorry. I'm afraid I only saw this about five minutes before you did.
What problems, though?
Look here. This mount design might look good, but in the middle of battle it's more liable to hinder me than protect my guns.
And here, this is nothing but a giant hole in my defenses. We'd be like doing the Morganas' work for them.
Oh, and this is one of the worst...

Fields.MenuText: All right, your point is well made. More thought should have gone into these designs.
You can calm down now.

Fields.DialogueText: Sí, Capitán. This is war, and we must give thorough thought to everything we do.
Lo siento, Capitán. I might've let myself get carried away there. You can look over the notes I made later.
Perhaps various navies would find such a design pleasing to the eye, but you know who else would find it pleasing? Our enemies. Our enemies and their weapons.
Captain, Velasco, we have Morganas approaching from the west.
Sound the alarm, and get ready for a fight.
Yes, Capitán, I'll just run to your cabin and leave my notes on your desk.
At least you have your priorities straight.
I fight Morganas with artillery, not with stacks of paper.
@BATTLE
Velasco!
You're not still sulking about getting that maintenance done, are you?
Maybe. Do you think it made any improvement?

Fields.MenuText: Better than I could've even imagined.
Honestly, the patches in your hull looked better. More character.
Not yet. Maybe a few years in the shipyard would do the trick, though.

Fields.DialogueText: Sí, Capitán. I'm starting to warm up to it too.
*sigh*
Aren't you just hilarious?
It's strange, not feeling the seams and scars from all my hasty repairs. At first I missed them, but overall I feel... more protected, I guess.
Good. That's what we were hoping for, after all.
We have Morganas headed this way, Captain. They're approaching from the south.
*sigh* This is why repairs never end...
Let's go! I'll tear them apart!
@BATTLE
You know, I'm standing right here.
The capitán is just being the capitán. Pay it no mind.
No... not really...
I know spending time with the engineers and doing maintenance isn't fun, but you must be feeling better, right?
Capitán, it's time!
Time for what? Judging by your smile, I'm going to assume it's not "Morgana fighting time."
You would be correct. It's actually time for you to join me on a run.

Fields.MenuText: Me? Run? You're hilarious. I'll be hiding in my cabin if you need me.
Hmmm, the weather is pretty gorgeous, right now. Sure, why not?
More running? What I wouldn't do for just a sliver of your inexhaustible energy.

Fields.DialogueText: You're not getting out of this that easily. You know you can't hide from me while we're on this ship.
That's the kind of attitude I'm looking for in a capitán!
I will take that as a yes, Capitán.
All right, then. Lead the way, Velasco.
Captain, we've detected incoming Morganas, closing fast!
Looks like we'll have to save our energy for battle. We can go for a run later.
Why wait? Let's try and make five laps around the ship before the battle starts. I'll race you!
I sincerely hope there are no Belles more energetic than her.
@BATTLE
Really, Capitán, is that really the best you can do? You're such a slowpoke!
Don't underestimate me! I'm just saving my energy for the Morganas.
That sounds more like an excuse to me.

Fields.MenuText: Very well. *hmph!* Is this more your speed?
Haha, I will not be goaded.
Maybe I should go slower - store up more energy.

Fields.DialogueText: Whoa, that's more like it. Now, it's a race!
It's only true running if you're out of breath by the finish line. Come on, Capitán!
Now you're just not being any fun at all.
Wait! Stop!
What, now you're tired? I don't believe that for a second.
No! I'm sensing several Morganas, north of us.
Told you it wasn't an excuse. I always need energy for the Morganas. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
See, I'm capable of speed, from time to time!
I know better than that, Velasco. I refuse to race when I know I'll lose.
You're the one who wanted to run.
@BATTLE
So... what exactly was that sound?
What sound?
That metallic clanking sound that I heard all the way from my cabin. The sound that made me afraid the ship was falling apart. The sound that...
*CLANK*
That sound.
Oh, that's nothing. Don't worry about it! Just the normal sounds of a ship that's been through hell and back.
You're not fooling me with that smile, Velasco.
Officer? What was that sound?
One of the 450mm torpedo tubes has been making odd noises for past few couple of skirmishes... and it's getting worse. We're all a little concerned.
Don't worry, Capitán! I'll take a peek at the tubes, see if I can't identify what's going on. I'm sure everything will be fine.

Fields.MenuText: Velasco, that might be true, but if something does go wrong then all the friends you've made on board could get hurt. I know you wouldn't want that.
I am the captain here, Velasco, and I make the orders. The torpedo tube needs to be replaced.
Velasco has a more intimate knowledge of the ship than any of us. I'm sure she'll figure out what's wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I wouldn't want anyone getting hurt. It might be smarter...
This ship is fine! Trust me, I know this ship better than any of you and I...
Thank you, Capitán. There's just a certain way you need to treat some of...
*GRRRRNNNK*
*BOOM*
That sounded even worse.
The tube had been patched, Captain, and it... fell apart.
Fell apart?
Like tissue paper, Captain.
So... out with the old, in with the new?
Yeah... okay...
Velasco, did you hear that?
That loud clanking noise? Nope!
If you didn't hear it, how did you know it was a clanking noise?
No time! Morganas incoming!
*CLANK*
How is the installation going below deck?
We're making steady progress. At this rate we should have the torpedo tube replaced on schedule.
And how about the rest of our artillery? Do we need to replace our guns as well?
Replace this! Replace that! At this rate you might as well just get a new ship...

Fields.MenuText: No one is getting a new ship. I'm just making sure we're ready to fight the Morganas.
I wasn't asking you. Your opinion is clearly biased.
You have a point. I'm sure the other weapons are fine.

Fields.DialogueText: I wish a Morgana would show up right about now. Then I could remind you what my guns are capable of.
Well... if you don't need my opinion then I guess I'll just go blow off some steam on deck.
Thank you, Capitán. You'll see what they're capable of during our next encounter with a Morgana.
Velasco is correct, Captain. The rest of the artillery is in adequate condition.
I told you!
Thanks, Officer, that will be all.
No, it won't. We have Morganas headed this way.
Sound the alarm.
Looks like it's time to show off my guns. My perfectly functional, absolutely adequate guns!
@BATTLE
How's it going, Velasco? Still getting used to things?
I miss some of the noises from my patchwork repairs. It feels like everything is changing around the ship.
That's just good maintenance. We need as much help fighting the Morganas as we can get.
I know. I understand... but my old ways got me through a lot of tough times.
I had to use the same techniques when fighting my sisters during the Spanish Civil War, and when I was outlawed as a pirate a few years ago...

Fields.MenuText: You had to fight your sisters?!
Wait, you were a pirate?
Quite the colorful past you have.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, it was a long time ago. Afterwards, we didn't stay angry at each other for long. It's all water under the bridge now.
We all have a past. I did a lot of things before finding you.
What can I say? My life has been a busy one, so far.
Saying goodbye to some of those old patches and lockwires felt like saying goodbye to old friends.
Never thought about it that way. I'm glad you told me. I feel like I understand you a little bit better now.
*ALARM*
Those Morganas sure don't know how to take a break.
No, they really don't. But maybe a distraction is just what I need.
Bring it on, you hideous mishmash of ships and ugly!
That's the spirit I've come to expect from you, Velasco!
@BATTLE
What's going on over here? Why are we firing guns? Did someone forget to set off the alarm again?
No, Captain. We were just testing the artillery.
Just having some fun, Capitán! We were seeing who could make the farthest shot. So far, I'm in the lead.
I'm convinced she's cheating. There's just no beating her.
Ha! You know I'm just too good!

Fields.MenuText: I call next.
You two realize that guns aren't intended for fun and games, right? They're meant for the opposite, actually.
All this noise is dangerous. What if you attracted some unfriendly eyes to our location?

Fields.DialogueText: Have at it, Capitán, but good luck beating my record!
Obviously, but I saw an opportunity for a little bit of fun and I took it. It's hardly a crime.
You're... right, I'm sorry. It was my idea, so if you have to punish anyone, punish me.
@BATTLE
How about this?
Not quite, Captain.
Ha! I remain victorious!
Captain, I'm sounding the alarm. We have inbound Morganas.
And that's why we don't play games with artillery.
You played too, Capitán.
I know, I know. Now let's take what we learned from our game and put it to good use.
Next time, think about how your fun might affect the rest of the crew.
Sí, Capitán.
I'm sorry too, Captain.
Captain, I'm sounding the alarm. We have inbound Morganas.
And that's why we don't play games with artillery.
Okay, in hindsight it wasn't the best idea.
You think?
No one's getting punished. Just put an end to the games immediately.
Yes, Captain.
Sí, Capitán.
Captain, I'm sounding the alarm. We have inbound Morganas.
And that's why we don't play games with artillery.
Are you sure we're still not getting punished?
Ask me again after the battle.
*BOOM*
*BOOM*
So, Capitán...
Hm?
I've been thinking.

Fields.MenuText: This can't be good.
Do share. I'm always interested to know what's on your mind.
Me, too. I've been thinking about my next meal. I'm starving.

Fields.DialogueText: At least let me tell you my idea before you start dreading it.
That's good to hear. I'll try and share more of my thoughts with you, then.
Well, if you can get your head out of your stomach for a second, I'll tell you what I've been thinking about.
I've been thinking that, if we have time, I'd like to stop by Cartagena for a spell.
Cartagena? In Spain?
Sí, Capitán. That's where I'm originally from. It's a truly remarkable place, with the fairest harbor in all of Spain.
Ah. Getting a little homesick, then?
Maybe. I know I can't stray too far from the ship, but just seeing the harbor again would be really nice. You know?
Spending too much time at sea can make anyone miss the familiar sights of home.
Perhaps. If we have time.
That's all I ask. Gracias.
*ALARM*
We won't be going anywhere until we take care of whatever is headed this way.
Then I better hurry!
Don't you always?
@BATTLE
Capitán, have you seen my hammer anywhere?
Your hammer?
Sí. The stonemason's hammer I carry with me. It has a carving of the symbol of the Navy of Nationalist Spain on it. I seem to have misplaced it, and it's quite dear to me.
Why not ask some of the crew help you look? I'm sure they'd be happy to assist.
No, no. I'd hate to bother them. I'm sure I can find it on my own. It couldn't have gone far...
Hmmmm... nope. Hmmmmmmmm... aqui? No. Martillo, come out to play!

Fields.MenuText: Would you like my help, Velasco?
Would you get out already? It's clearly not in here.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I'll find it! Don't mind me.
Rude! But you do have a point. I guess I'll look somewhere else.
Are you under the Capitán's desk? Nope. Maybe I left you over heeeeere?
Captain, Velasco, we have a Morgana approaching from the south.
Let's get this over with. The faster we win the battle, the faster I can get back to finding my hammer!
From what I could see, you weren't finding anything...
@BATTLE
How's it going, Vel--
It's not going at all! Have you seen my hammer anywhere? I still can't find it and I've looked everywhere!
What's the big deal? Just a hammer, right? We can get you a new one.
But it's... my hammer...
Ah, now I see.

Fields.MenuText: It was expensive, wasn't it?
It's sentimental.
On second thought, no. I still don't get it.

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, it was free. It was a gift.
Only in that I owned it.
Yeah, neither do I. For all I know, it fell into the ocean and has already sunk to the seafloor.
Ay! Qué horrible! Everything's changing around me, but I thought my hammer was one thing I could keep! And now I've lost it...
I'm sorry... but things change, Velasco. And change can be good. This conversation is proof of that, if you think about it.
How can the two of us talking be proof?
Not long ago, people would have thought me insane if I said I regularly conversed with my ship. Now we have Belles - a pretty big change in the world if you ask me. A good change.
You're forgetting one thing, Capitán.
And what's that?
Morganas inbound!
Them. Are they an example of a good change, too?
@BATTLE
Still no luck finding your hammer?
No, but I'm not losing hope.
I'll find it. Even if I have to dive to the depths to do so.

Fields.MenuText: That's some serious commitment you have.
Whoa, calm down. It's just a hammer.
With that attitude, I'm sure it'll be back in your grasp soon.

Fields.DialogueText: It's important to me. I can't just forget about it.
It's not just a hammer. It's my companion. It's been with me for a long time.
I hope you're right. I'd also appreciate it if you could keep an eye out for it, too.
Well, I was thinking that our next destination could be Cartegena.
Cartagena? Really?
I figured you might like that plan.
It would be great to go home for a while! Gracias, Capitán!
Oh, Miss Velasco, there you are! I've been looking all over for you.
Hey, did you need something from me?
No, I was just returning your hammer. I couldn't find you, so I put it by your door. I hope that's okay.
Wait, you had my hammer? Why?
I wanted to try my hand at a little sculpting in my room. I thought your hammer might be good for it, so you let me borrow it. Remember?
Not... even a little bit.
Huh, that's weird, I could have sworn that you heard me. Sorry ‘bout that.
My hammer! Did you hear that, Capitán? My hammer is safe and sound...
This doesn't change our destination does it?
*ALARM*
No, but that might.
I'll be right back, I just need my hammer!
That's the fastest I've seen her run.
And that's saying something, Captain.
@BATTLE
I guess I can respect that. But maybe you'd be open to a pleasant distraction?
Still, it's a hammer. We'll probably see dozens like it at our next stop.
Next stop?
I can keep an eye out, but I was actually thinking of doing something else to cheer you up.
And how exactly were you planning on cheering me up, Capitán?
Distraction?
So, Capitán, we should reach Cartagena any time now, right? Right? Right?
About that, Velasco... sit down.
This doesn't sound like good news.
HQ reported that a large group of Morganas has set up near Cartagena. If we get too close, there's a good chance we'll draw them to us.
I see... so what's our plan, Capitán?

Fields.MenuText: I figure we "pull a Velasco" and run straight for them, maybe catch them off guard.
I think we should head to the port and hope they don't spot us.
What do you think we should do?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not crazy about the name, but I'm in love with the idea. Let's do it!
It's not how I would do it, but you are the capitán!
I think we should face them head on. It'll take more than a few Morganas to stop me.
Well, that's our plan then. Let's head to Cartagena.
My stomach is doing somersaults, I'm so excited. I have to run a few laps before I throw up!
That might be the first time I heard someone talk about throwing up with a smile on their face.
@BATTLE
Phew, that Morgana resistance was a bit worse than I had expected.
No matter! Look, Capitán, I can see Cartagena in the distance. Isn't it beautiful?
Cartagena, huh? Velasco was right, it's a beautiful city.
I don't get a lot of free time off the ship, but I'm glad I was able to make time for this.
Too bad Velasco couldn't join me, though.
You, you with the uniform!
Me?
Sí! You! Wouldn't you like to buy something nice? Maybe something for that certain special someone?
Heh. No, thanks.
At least take a look! I have some of the finest cloth in all of Spain, I have the most magnificent wine, and you can never go wrong with flowers.
Flowers? Those look quite nice, actually. I suppose Velasco might like one. What's this dark red one called?
That, my friend, is a carnation. The deeper the red, the deeper the love it symbolizes. A truly perfect gift for the one you love.
Hmmmm. It's a symbol of love...

Fields.MenuText: No. I wouldn't want to send her the wrong message.
It's perfect - I'll take it.

Fields.DialogueText: Then a white carnation for a dear friend. Here you are!
Wonderful. Here you are. May it serve you well!
Captain, you better get back to the ship! We have some Morganas headed this direction!
I'll be right there!
